description.catalog: This course will introduce the methods used to properly conduct a digital forensics investigation including device, network and cloud forensics. As part of this course, the core competencies of the International Association of Computer Investigative Specialists (IACIS) Certified Forensic Computer Examiner (CFCE) program are covered.
description.expanded: Topics covered include an overview of computer forensics as a profession; the computer investigation process; understanding operating systems boot processes and disk structures; network forensics; malware forensics; and technical report writing. Students successfully completing this course will also qualify for EC-Council's Computer Hacking Forensic Investigator (CHFI) certification exam.

purpose.why: Digital forensics is a rapidly growing field essential for cybersecurity, law enforcement, and corporate investigations. This course prepares you for professional certifications (IACIS CFCE, EC-Council CHFI, GIAC GCFE/GCFA) and provides hands-on experience with industry-standard forensic tools and methodologies.
purpose.beyond: Beyond technical skills, you'll develop critical thinking, attention to detail, and professional documentation skills that are valuable in any investigative or analytical role. You'll learn to follow rigorous procedures, maintain chain of custody, and communicate technical findings to diverse audiences.

slos: Describe the fundamental concepts of incident response and forensic investigation
Conduct thorough examinations of computer hard disk drives, and other electronic data storage media to recover information and electronic data
Perform data collection using forensic technology methods in accordance with evidence handling procedures
Be able to generate reports which detail the approach and provide an audit trail that supports the integrity of the investigation process and any actions taken

phases.title: Phase 1: Forensics Foundations (Weeks 1-3)
phases.description: Introduction to digital forensics profession, investigation process, and legal framework

topics: Overview of digital forensics as a profession
Role in incident response and cybersecurity
Industry certifications (IACIS CFCE, GIAC GCFE, EC-Council CHFI)
Course overview and lab environment setup
weeks.readings: Introduction to Digital Forensics (online resources); NIST SP 800-86 (overview)
assignments: Lab Activity 1: Forensic Workstation Setup (20 pts)
Discussion Post 1: Career Paths in Digital Forensics (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Set up forensic tools and virtual machines

topics: Chain of custody and evidence handling
weeks.readings: NIST SP 800-86: Guide to Integrating Forensic Techniques
assignments: Lab Activity 2: Chain of Custody Documentation Exercise (20 pts)
Discussion Post 2: Investigation Process Best Practices (3 pts)
Homework 1: Forensic Investigation Workflow Diagram (20 pts)

topics: Laws governing digital evidence (Federal Rules, Daubert Standard)
Code of ethics for forensic investigators
weeks.readings: Fourth Amendment and Digital Evidence; SWGDE Best Practices
assignments: Lab Activity 3: Legal Case Study Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 3: Ethics in Digital Forensics (3 pts)
Quiz 1: Legal & Ethical Principles + Investigation Process (30 pts)

phases.title: Phase 2: Storage and File Systems (Weeks 4-6)
phases.description: Understanding hardware, file systems, and forensic imaging techniques

topics: Computer hardware components relevant to forensics
Hard disk drive (HDD) vs Solid State Drive (SSD) architecture
weeks.readings: Understanding Disk Structures and Boot Processes
assignments: Lab Activity 4: Storage Device Examination and Boot Process Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 4: HDD vs SSD Forensic Implications (3 pts)

topics: File system fundamentals (FAT, exFAT, NTFS, ext2/3/4, HFS+, APFS)
Deleted file recovery and file carving
assignments: Lab Activity 5: File System Analysis and Deleted File Recovery (20 pts)
Discussion Post 5: File System Comparison (NTFS vs ext4) (3 pts)
Homework 2: Master File Table (MFT) Analysis Report (20 pts)
Lab Activity 6: Forensic Imaging and Hash Verification (20 pts)
Discussion Post 6: Write Blocker Technologies (3 pts)
Quiz 2: Hardware, File Systems, and Data Acquisition (30 pts)

phases.title: Phase 3: Operating System Forensics (Weeks 7-10)
phases.description: Windows and Linux forensics, event logs, registry analysis, and memory forensics

topics: Windows Registry structure and forensic value
assignments: Lab Activity 7: Windows Registry Analysis for User Activity (20 pts)
Discussion Post 7: Windows Artifact Timeline Reconstruction (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Registry analysis with RegRipper and Eric Zimmerman tools

assignments: Lab Activity 8: Windows Event Log Analysis and Prefetch Examination (20 pts)
Discussion Post 8: NTFS Artifact Significance (3 pts)
Homework 3: Security Incident Investigation Using Event Logs (20 pts)
Lab Activity 9: Linux System Investigation and Log Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 9: Linux vs Windows Forensic Approaches (3 pts)
Midterm Exam: Comprehensive Exam Covering Weeks 1-8 (120 pts)
weeks.notes: MIDTERM EXAM - covers all material from Weeks 1-8

assignments: Lab Activity 10: Memory Acquisition and Analysis with Volatility (20 pts)
Discussion Post 10: Volatile Data Forensic Value (3 pts)

phases.title: Phase 4: Network and Advanced Forensics (Weeks 11-15)
phases.description: Network forensics, malware analysis, mobile forensics, and cloud investigations

topics: Packet capture with Wireshark and tcpdump
assignments: Lab Activity 11: Packet Capture and Analysis with Wireshark (20 pts)
Discussion Post 11: Network Forensics Challenges (3 pts)

topics: Web server log analysis (Apache, IIS, nginx)
SQL injection and XSS attack investigation
assignments: Lab Activity 12: Web Server Log Analysis and Attack Investigation (20 pts)
Discussion Post 12: Web Attack Indicators (3 pts)
Quiz 3: Windows/Linux Forensics, Memory & Network Forensics (30 pts)
Homework 4: Network Intrusion Timeline Report (20 pts)

topics: Static malware analysis (strings, PE headers, hashes)
assignments: Lab Activity 13: Static and Dynamic Malware Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 13: Malware Analysis Techniques (3 pts)
weeks.notes: Malware analysis in controlled sandbox environment

assignments: Lab Activity 14: Android Device Forensic Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 14: Mobile vs Desktop Forensics (3 pts)
Homework 5: Mobile App Artifact Analysis Report (20 pts)
Final Project Proposal: Forensic Investigation Case (Required - 0 pts)
weeks.notes: Final project proposal due - required for final project

topics: Cloud service models and forensic challenges
Cloud evidence acquisition (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud)
assignments: Lab Activity 15: Cloud Service Log Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 15: Cloud Forensics Challenges (3 pts)
Quiz 4: Malware, Mobile, and Cloud Forensics (30 pts)

phases.title: Phase 5: Professional Reporting and Capstone (Weeks 16-17)
phases.description: Email forensics, professional reporting, and final project completion

assignments: Lab Activity 16: Email Investigation and Phishing Analysis (20 pts)
Discussion Post 16: Emerging Forensics Technologies (3 pts)
Lab Activity 17: Professional Forensic Report Writing (20 pts)
Discussion Post 17: Course Reflection and Career Planning (3 pts)
Quiz 5: Reporting, Ethics, and Comprehensive Review (30 pts)
Final Project: Complete Forensic Investigation Report and Presentation (120 pts)
Final Exam: Comprehensive Final Exam (120 pts)
weeks.notes: FINAL WEEK - Last day of semester is Friday, May 22

required.title: Computer Forensics Lab
required.notes: Access to specialized forensic workstations and tools

recommended.title: Computer Forensics and Investigations
recommended.author: Bill Nelson, Amelia Phillips, Christopher Steuart

free.title: NIST SP 800-86
free.notes: Guide to Integrating Forensic Techniques into Incident Response

free.title: SANS DFIR Blog
free.notes: Digital forensics and incident response articles

importantDates.event: Last day to add without instructor signature
Final Project and Final Exam Due; Last day of instruction

workload.note: Final project requires approximately 15 hours total work in Weeks 14-17. Time commitment varies by week - homework and exam weeks require more hours.

components.description: Hands-on forensic analysis and tool practice
Weekly reflection posts and peer engagement
Complete forensic investigation report and presentation

grading.bonusOpportunities: Up to 30 extra credit points available through professional development activities (conferences, CTF competitions, tutorial creation). All extra credit must be approved in advance and completed by Week 16.
grading.passingGrade: C (70%) required for CSC majors and to progress to advanced cybersecurity courses

policies.attendance: Regular attendance is essential for success. Lab activities cannot be made up except in cases of documented emergencies or illness. Missing more than 3 labs without valid documentation may result in a failing grade.
policies.lateWork: Lab Activities: 10% per day late, maximum 3 days. Homework: 10% per day late, maximum 5 days. Quizzes: No makeup without documentation. Discussion Posts: 50% penalty if late, maximum 2 days. Final Project: 20% per day late, maximum 2 days. Exams: No makeup without documentation; schedule within 1 week.
policies.makeupWork: Quizzes and exams cannot be made up without documented emergency. Contact instructor within 24 hours for quizzes, 48 hours for other emergencies. Labs and homework can be completed late with penalties as noted.
policies.academicIntegrity: All work submitted must be your own. Collaboration is encouraged on labs and discussions but written submissions must be individual unless specifically designated as group work. Use of AI tools for code generation or analysis is permitted but must be documented and cited. Copying forensic reports or presenting others' analysis as your own constitutes academic dishonesty. First offense: Zero on assignment + academic integrity meeting. Second offense: Failing grade in course + referral to college administration.
policies.collaboration: Encouraged: Discussing concepts, troubleshooting tools, comparing approaches. Permitted: Helping classmates understand errors or techniques. Prohibited: Copying lab reports, sharing quiz answers, submitting identical work.
policies.aiUsage: Generative AI can be used in specific assignments in this course. Students will receive guidelines for using AI responsibly, with clear expectations on what is permitted and how to cite your usage. The use of AI tools beyond the guidelines of each assignment is considered plagiarism in this course, and disciplinary actions fall under the plagiarism guidelines.

successTips: Document everything - assume your work may be used in court. Proper documentation is a core forensic skill.
Master the core tools early - spend extra time with Autopsy, Volatility, and Wireshark in the first weeks.
Start homework and projects early - forensic analysis takes longer than you think.
Practice with additional datasets beyond assigned work - repetition builds proficiency.
Join online forensics communities (Reddit r/computerforensics, DFIR Discord) for support and learning.
Follow current forensic cases and techniques in the news - connect concepts to real-world applications.
Keep detailed lab notebooks with screenshots and observations - these help with reports and studying.
Review tool documentation and tutorials - many have advanced features not covered in class.
Consider certification preparation - this course aligns with CFCE, CHFI, GCFE, and GCFA exams.
Attend all labs - hands-on practice with instructor guidance is invaluable and cannot be replicated independently.
